Dear Ms. Brewer:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. You must contest or agree to the
issuance of a provisional license in writing, on the CWL-4617 within 15 days, with
submission of the corrective action plan. If you do not submit the CWL-4617, it will be
treated as contested. Even if you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must
still submit an acceptable corrective action plan.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms
of intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth have been hit by the Chief Administrator.
Investigation The Complainant was contacted on 01/09/2024 and had no
additional information to report.
The Licensee Designee confirmed in email communication on
01/16/2024 after it was initially requested on 01/10/2024, that a
safety plan had been put in place for the Chief Administrator in
response to the allegations that she had pushed or hit youth in the
program. The safety plan consisted of split shifts where half of the
day the Chief Administrator was not in contact with youth and
performing administrative duties, and the other half of the day the
Chief Administrator was only monitoring staff and youth and not
having direct contact with youth. It was later confirmed that the
Chief Administrator stopped working at the facility as of
02/05/2024.
Incident 1
Youth A was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at her school. In this
interview she alleged the Chief Administrator had pushed Youth C
during an incident in the visitation room of the facility. Youth A
recalled being downstairs in the visitation room with Youth C at
night when they were supposed to be in bed. The Chief
Administrator opened the sliding door to the room and asked them
to go back to bed. Youth A recalled Youth C standing up from the
couch and approaching the Chief Administrator. She believed the
Chief Administrator said “Don’t walk up on me” in response to
2

Youth C, and then pushed Youth C’s forehead. Youth A recalled
Youth C then falling back onto the couch. Youth A did not believe
Youth C touched the Chief Administrator while this occurred.
Youth C was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
recalled the incident alleged by Youth A. Youth C stated she and
Youth A were in the visitation room of the facility when they were
supposed to be in their bedrooms. Youth C recalled Chief
Administrator coming in to the room and asking them to go back to
their rooms. Youth C stated back to her that she was not going to
do that. Youth C admitted that she “got up in the face” of the
Chief Administrator only for her to push Youth C on her forehead
with the palm of her hand. Youth C stated that she fell backwards
a little bit, but not all the way to the ground. Youth C stated she
then walked past the Chief Administrator and that they continued
to argue, but this was the end of any physical contact between the
two for this incident.
Youth D was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
stated she believed she witnessed the Chief Administrator punch
Youth A during the incident in question where Youth A and Youth
C were in the visitation room, but she could not provide any other
notable details. Youth D stated she was on the other side of the
dining area and saw past the Chief Administrator into the visitation
room.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with
DHHS Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the
facility. She recalled the incident in question where Youth A and
Youth C were in the visitation room when they should have been
in their bedrooms. The Chief Administrator stated that she
entered the room to see both Youth A and Youth C laying on the
ground and the couch, respectively. The Chief Administrator
recalled Youth C stood up and stepped towards her. She then
extended her arm out towards Youth C and could not recall if that
is when she made contact with Youth C. The Chief Administrator
stated Youth C then “ran into her” by bumping her shoulder as the
youth walked past and then ran out of the room. The Chief
Administrator could not recall exactly what was being said at that
moment. The Chief Administrator denied ever pushing or hitting
any youth in the program at any time.
3

Documents reviewed:
• An Incident Report regarding Youth C dated 12/18/2023
was provided. This was authored by the Chief
Administrator. It stated Youth C was refusing to sleep in
their room and were on the couch of the visitation room at
the time of the writing of the Incident report. It also
described Youth C as aggressive and “walking up on staff”
but no specific details were written to describe this
behavior.
• Documentation from the personnel file for the Chief
Administrator was reviewed. There were no incidents of
discipline in her file. It was noted that a safety plan was put
in place by the program on 11/06/2023 containing the
following elements: “Chief Administrator to work 20hrs per
week on the floor and remaining hours monitoring staff,
youth and all CAPs.”
• Video footage specific to this incident was requested.
There was not any footage that was able to be produced
that would show the entrance to the visitation room or the
point in time when Youth A and Youth C were in there and
the Chief Administrator approached them. Footage that
was provided was purportedly from later in the same
evening and began with the Chief Administrator sitting at
the dining room table with Youth C and Staff 1. Youth C
stood up and exited the dining area to the left of the
security camera and the Chief Administrator followed her.
The Chief Administrator could be heard stating “Come
here, [Youth C]” and then she moved to the left out of view.
The Chief Administrator then was seen in the left corner of
the footage reaching out, and then Youth C came into view.
The Chief Administrator pushed Youth C with her right
hand and Youth C fell out of the bottom of the view of the
security footage.
Incident 2
Youth A was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at her school. During
this interview she alleged that Chief Administrator had hit her
while in the car with Youth D. She stated that the three individuals
were on their way to the local soup kitchen where the youth
volunteer. Youth A recalled she was sitting in the front passenger
seat, and Youth D was sitting in the back of the van. Youth A
recalled Chief Administrator reaching over while driving and
smacking Youth A on the side of her face. After they had stopped
at a gas station, Youth A and Youth D had switched seats. Youth
4

A recalled the Chief Administrator later reached back and
attempted to hit Youth A while driving and on the phone.
Youth C was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
described a similar incident to Youth A where she alleged the
Chief Administrator slapped her while in the car. Youth C recalled
a time where she got in the car with the Chief Administrator to be
transported to school. Youth C stated she and the Chief
Administrator were arguing about something she could not recall
when the Chief Administrator reached over and “tapped” her on
the cheek. Youth C alternated between referring to this physical
contact as a tap and a slap. She stated no one else was in the
car with her when this occurred. Youth C could not provide any
other details or a date when this occurred.
Youth D was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
could not recall the incident in question regarding Chief
Administrator using physical contact with Youth A while in the car.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with
DHHS Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the
facility. She stated she was “not sure” of the specific incidents
that were alleged where she had slapped Youth A or Youth C
while in the car. She did state there was one time when she was
driving and she felt she had to “wave off” the youth in the car with
her because they were loud and she was on the phone. The
Chief Administrator could not recall exactly who was in the car for
this situation. She did describe something she believed she did
with youth often, and this was something that Youth C may have
been referring to. The Chief Administrator stated she often would
use her hand to touch beneath the chin of youth she was speaking
to and lift their heads up. The Chief Administrator stated she did
this to teach the youth the importance of making eye contact with
whomever they were speaking with. Chief Administrator stated
she did not ask for consent to touch youth in this manner when
she did this. The Chief Administrator denied ever doing anything
disparaging to youth in the program.
Incident 3
Youth A was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at her school. She
recalled an incident where Staff 2 had pinched her fingers in the
sliding door to the office of the facility. Youth A stated the sliding
5

door was closed and may have been locked. She knew at the
time that she was not allowed in this room. Youth A recalled Staff
2 pushing the sliding door backward and in doing so, it pinched
Youth A’s fingers. Youth A believed this was done on purpose as
a way to stop her from getting into that restricted area. Youth A
did not believe she was injured during this incident and did not
believe she received medical attention afterwards. Youth A stated
she has not seen Staff 2 since this incident.
Youth D was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
stated she witnessed Youth A get her fingers pressed behind the
sliding door to the facility office by Staff 2 when Youth A was
attempting to break into the room. Youth D did not have any other
specifics to provide regarding the incident.
During a video conference on 02/01/2024 DHHS Worker 1 stated
that their investigation would not produce any findings.
Documents reviewed:
• An Incident Report regarding Youth A dated 01/07/2024
was provided. In it, Youth A was described as attempting
to break into the staff office of the facility. Staff 2 stated in
this report that Youth A attempted to lift up the door to the
office, but that Staff 2 held the door down. Youth A then
stated her fingers were smashed as this occurred. Staff 2
documented this could have occurred and if it did it was an
accident. It was noted Staff 2 was sent home from work at
the time of that incident.
• Video footage from the date and time of this incident was
provided but was not conclusive. The footage showed
Youth A and Staff 2 in the dining area of the facility but the
part of the incident where they were at the staff office door
was not shown.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documentation
reviewed, there was evidence found that supports a rule violation
for staff pushing youth during altercations at the facility.
Technical assistance provided:
• Alterations to procedures are needed regarding the
communication and provision of necessary documents for
investigations. One request for documentation is all that is
necessary for the program to have an organized and timely
manner of returning information and documentation.
6

• The facility has been advised to find a different service to
use for security camera systems. The current system can
allow for high quality footage and audio recordings but has
proven to be too difficult for staff to use. Continued use of
this system will risk non-compliance when video footage is
required to be provided as well as continued missed
opportunity to review incidents and use that footage for
training and debriefing purposes.
• The creation of policy and procedures specific to the use of
video security systems and the access of video clips for the
use in debriefing, training and investigative purposes is
advised as well.
• Effort is needed to train and review incident reports for
necessary details. It is not sufficient for the program to
write vague descriptions of youth or staff behaviors; all
necessary details are required to be outlined in that
documentation to ensure it is accurate.
• Safety plans instituted by the facility for staff need to be
more specific and be able to have the desired effect. If any
staff member has allegations involving the physical safety
of youth or allegations of any verbal altercations with youth,
it is insufficient to arrange for them to still be in the
presence of youth expect there to be no interaction
between the staff and youth. In addition, any safety plan
that requires a staff member to commit time specifically to
administrative tasks should produce measurable outcomes
for those tasks.
Consultation provided:
• Consideration is required in the area of any physical
contact with youth. Even well-intended physical contact
can trigger a youth and cause undue stress when it has not
been invited and consented. The physical contact
described by the Chief Administrator does not reflect a
trauma informed approach to communicating with the youth
that will be typically placed in this program.
Conclusion Violation Established
7

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms
of intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative
references to a youth’s background or appearance
or mental state. Yelling, threats, ridicule, or
humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Chief Administrator made a disparaging comment to Youth C.
Investigation Documentation reviewed:
• Video footage from 12/18/2023 regarding Incident 1 as
described in the allegations for CCI Rule 400.4158 (1) (a)
(ii) was reviewed. The footage did not have an exact time,
but it was confirmed this occurred after Youth C attempted
to sleep in the visitation room of the facility, had escalated
behavior and then began to calm down. At the beginning of
this footage the Chief Administrator was sitting across the
table of Youth C in the dining area of the facility, with Staff
1 standing next to them. Youth C can be seen briefly with a
look of upset on her face. The Chief Administrator had
looked at Youth C and can clearly be heard stating
"Crybaby" towards Youth C. She then stood up from the
table and stated "C'mon, let's go" and "Let's ride" as they
walked toward the left side of the security footage. This is
where the description of pushing by the Chief Administrator
occurred referenced previously in this report.
Analysis Through documentation reviewed there was sufficient evidence
found to support a rule violation in that the Chief Administrator
used derogatory language towards Youth C after an incident had
de-escalated.
Conclusion Violation Established
8

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149 Resident nutrition
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible
Description meals daily unless medically contraindicated and
documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth have not been properly fed meals.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at her school. She
stated she has concerns over the amount of food that youth are
served in the program. Youth A stated an example dinner recently
included a cheeseburger (with a bun) and potato salad with a fruit
cup on the side. She recalled breakfast from earlier that day
being cereal, milk and a packaged yogurt. Youth A stated
common snacks were fruit and fruit snacks. Youth A clarified she
had never been served or had seen baby food in the facility but
had expressed concerns about food to others and had stated she
believed they were served “baby sized” portions of food.
Youth B was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
stated she was offered cereal for breakfast that morning but chose
to only have yogurt. Youth B stated her recent AWOL from the
facility was in part caused by not being allowed to eat enough to
her liking. She described lunches consisting of peanut butter and
jelly sandwiches and chips with fruit on the side. Youth B did state
that youth in the program were provided snacks after school and
on the weekends.
Youth C was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
believed they were served “baby sized” portions and she has
resorted to stealing food because she was hungry. Youth C could
not recall much of what is offered to eat because she didn't like it,
and referred to often eating peanut butter and jelly sandwiches as
an alternative. Youth C described restrictive rules on eating, such
as only being offered a fruit within 30 minutes after dinner if youth
are still hungry, but not being able to do so after that time.
Youth D was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
stated youth are served small portions, but she felt like the
portions were “reasonable.” Youth D commented that a recent
dinner was a hot dog and a bun with fruit on the side. She stated
9

that they often eat cereal for breakfast. Youth D also stated they
usually get snacks but there have been recent times when that did
not occur.
The facility was toured on two different occasions during
unannounced visits, on 01/09/2024 and 01/30/2024. The
refrigerator, freezer, and storage space in the kitchen and the
basement of the building were viewed. On both occasions there
was sufficient fresh, frozen, dry and canned food available.
Documentation reviewed:
• Menus from the facility were documented on two different
occasions. The meal options and alternatives described on
the menus were appropriate and sufficient.
• Video footage showing six different examples of youth
sitting down to eat dinner was requested and reviewed. At
no point did it appear that youth had amounts or portions of
food that were insufficient.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documentation
reviewed, there was no evidence found that the youth are not
being provided adequate food.
Technical assistance provided:
• The program is advised to redesign their policies and
procedures surrounding food. While it was not found that
youth are not being fed, it was clear that the restrictive
nature regarding the timing and scheduling of meals and
snacks and the amounts and types of food served was not
serving the youth well. It was a frequent complaint and
source of consternation from youth and is likely providing
opportunity for conflict when there could be less of it.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the
Description direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable
interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time between the
variable interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff members are not supervising the youth at night because they
fall asleep and do not make the required eyes on checks.
10

Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at her school. She
recalled an instance where she and other youth in the program
were making an attempt to AWOL, and in doing so she believed
that Staff 1 was asleep. Youth A stated this occurred late at night.
Youth A stated she believed Staff 1 was asleep because she saw
Staff 1’s eyes closed on one occasion as she quickly moved
through the hallway. Youth A was not sure if she saw Staff 1 after
that as she and other youth attempted to AWOL.
Youth D was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. Youth D
stated she knew Staff 1 had fallen asleep on a recent evening shift
because Youth D went through the hallway in an attempt to AWOL
and she saw Staff 1 with her eyes closed. Youth D believed Staff
1 would have easily noticed her walking towards the stairs
otherwise.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the program. Staff 1
denied ever falling asleep while working overnight shifts at the
program. She stated she sometimes sits at the end of the hallway
where all the entrances to the bedrooms are located, and
sometimes in the “Think Tank” room, which is an all-purpose room
at the end of that hallway.
Documentation reviewed:
• Video footage lasting 20 seconds from the evening of
01/17/2024 was provided and reviewed. The timing of the
video could not be provided by the facility. This showed
Staff 1 awake and working on documentation while sitting
in a chair at the end of the hallway. This footage was brief
and no other video footage was available from the facility
during the hours where the youth were asleep.
• Third shift logs from the evenings several nights in
December and early January were provided and reviewed.
There were multiple examples of documentation showing
exact 15 minute eyes on checks of youth during sleeping
hours.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and documentation reviewed, there
was sufficient evidence found to show that staff have not been
providing variable eyes on checks of youth during sleeping hours
and have been falling asleep during overnight shifts.
Conclusion Violation Established
11

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents’ needs, implementation of treatment plans,
and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff are not following facility policy on safe driving with youth.
Investigation The Chief Administrator was interviewed on 01/18/2024 with
DHHS Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the
program. While describing one of the incidents that led to
allegations of inappropriate physical contact between her and
Youth A, the Chief Administrator stated she was speaking on her
phone while driving. She stated she does this on occasion while
transporting youth. The Chief Administrator could not recall if that
was a work related phone call or a personal call. She also
confirmed she was aware of newer Michigan laws that do not
allow hand held cell phones to be used while driving other than
through a car’s audio system and confirmed she was not on
speaker phone in front of the youth. The Chief Administrator
stated she was not sure what the facility policies were regarding
personal phone use.
Documentation reviewed:
• Facility policy last dated 06/27/2023 was reviewed. In a
section titled “Transportation” it is stated that “cell phones
are not to be used while driving vehicles.”
Analysis Through an interview with staff and documentation reviewed there
was evidence found to show that staff are not following their
policies regarding the safe transportation of youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2023C0000695 dated 10/05/2023, CAP approved 11/16/2023
12

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4116 Chief administrator; responsibilities.
Section (1) An agency shall assign the chief administrator
Description responsibility for the onsite day-to-day operation of the
institution and for ensuring compliance with these rules.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Chief Administrator did not carry out required responsibilities.
Investigation Interviews with staff and youth and video footage reviewed
provided evidence that the Chief Administrator pushed a youth
and made disparaging comments to her. In interviews for this
investigation the Chief Administrator denied ever hitting or pushing
youth and denied ever doing anything disparaging towards them.
The Chief Administrator was found to have violated the agencies
policy and Michigan law when using her handheld device while
transporting youth.
During the 01/18/2024 face-to-face interview the Chief
Administrator stated she recognized she was the leader of the
day-to-day operations of the program and believed that she
needed to set an example for all staff on how to best interact with
the youth.
Analysis Through interviews with staff and youth and documentation
reviewed there was evidence found that the Chief Administrator
failed to ensure compliance with all Licensing rules through her
own actions of violating agency policies, pushing a youth and
making disparaging comments towards a youth.
Conclusion Violation Established
13

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the license be modified to a First Provisional license.
